title: Planet Gemini PDA Hands-On: The Dream Of The 90s Is Alive
description: The Planet Gemini feels like a device from some alternate universe where the Personal Digital Assistant never died. Its eyeglass-case chassis evokes the old Sony Tablet P, while its miniature QWERTY keyboard suggests a laptop that stumbled into a shrinking machine. But its closest relative is probably the Psion PDA from the 1990s, a device beloved as much for its powerful scheduling software as for its robust physical keyboard.   The Planet Gemini is no mere throwback. Its available in WiFi and 4G versions (for both GSM and CDMA networks), it dual-boots Android and Linux, and you can even make phone calls on it. Planet says the Gemini is meant for bloggers, longform writers and other creators who live and die by a physical keyboard, and its easy to see why itd be a tempting purchase for such folks. Still, its hard to envision many people ponying up for a device that slots in somewhere between the smartphone and laptop, yet professes to replace neither.   Of course, you dont *need* to imagine it; you can just head on over to Planets Indiegogo page (down below) to see how many customers have already devoted their dollars to picking up a Gemini of their own. If youre keen to join them, the Planet Gemini is available for $299 or $399 in WiFi and 4G versions, respectively, with units already in production. The Planet Gemini ships to early backers later this month; deliveries will continue into the spring, at which point Ill hopefully follow up with a full review. transcript: - [Narrator] Back in the 1990s, when cellphones and PDAs were still separate things, over a million people bought something called the Psion, a durable clamshell organizer with reliable software and a large keyboard. 20 years later, the Psion's spiritual successor has finally arrived. From CES 2018 in Las Vegas, I'm Mr. Mobile with a first look at the Gemini from Planet Computers. (grungy electronic music) Yeah, but, what is it? That's the number-one question I overheard during my brief time with the Gemini on the show floor, and, you know, it's an understandable one. This thing isn't much bigger than a large smartphone. Some versions of it have 4G builtin. And you can even make calls on it. Yet, it's not intended to be a smartphone replacement. Planet says the Gemini was built to be a tool for creators: bloggers, social-media mavens, people whose workdays are measured in emails per hour. And the core feature for that audience is, of course, the physical keyboard. While it's usable as a thumb-board, it's really meant for a tabletop, and making that possible is an ingenious folding metal extension that slides out from the hinge when opened, keeping it balanced while you're clacking away. Much like a Blackberry, there are function shortcuts mapped to some of the keys that let you change the screen brightness, or adjust the volume, or call up the emoji panel. Some of the software, like the Agenda, was heavily inspired by the Psion of the '90s. Where the old Psion had a row of physical buttons for shortcuts, the Gemini uses a popover panel in software that you can customize yourself. If you want more real estate than the six-inch display gives you, you can pick up an HDMI adapter to plug into a bigger monitor through one of the USB-C ports. And if you need a little more precision than the touchscreen offers, you can pair a Bluetooth mouse, as well. While there's no external display, there is an LED strip that's programmable. So you can set color sequences for specific alerts, like email or reminders or phone calls. Those phone calls are pretty neat since the two ports on the front are both speaker and microphone. So, there is no upside-down or right-side-up; you just hold it to your head, and talk. If video calls are more your speed, there's a five-megapixel front-facing webcam and your choice of side-firing loudspeakers or a headphone jack. And if Android isn't enough to sate your mobile-computing needs, you do have the option to boot into Linux, as well. As excited as I am about the Gemini bringing back the dream of the '90s, I do have a couple concerns. For one thing, it's running last-year's Android Nougat, apparently because Oreo support has yet to arrive for the MediaTek chipset this thing is built on. Also, I wasn't really encouraged by my first few minutes with the keyboard. First off, there's no backlight, which is a big downer. And secondly, I felt like the keys were on the mushy side. I had to really punch down on some of 'em to get keystrokes to register. Remember, I'm at CES, and this was a preproduction model pulled off the assembly line days ago. I'll need a full review out in the real world with a retail model to evaluate it properly. The Planet Gemini is the product of an Indiegogo campaign that's still rolling on. Buyers have their option of WiFi-only and cellular models, the latter of which is compatible with both GSM and CDMA networks. Yay for Verizon and Sprint. At press time, the WiFi model is available for $299. The 4G version is 399. And a variety of accessories are on offer, including an external camera for an extra 49 bucks. I'll drop the link to the campaign in the description below. Those who backed early on will start getting their units later this month, with deliveries continuing through the spring. And, hopefully, review devices will start landing on desks like mine soon, too. If that happens, those following me on Instagram at theMrMobile will be the first to see the unboxing.
